refnamediv.refpurpose: Local machine ID and secret configuration files

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The /etc/machine-id and /etc/machine-secret files contain the unique machine identifiers of the local system set during installation. Each of them contains a single newline-terminated, hexadecimal, 32-character, lowercase string. When decoded from hexadecimal, this corresponds with a 16-byte/128-bit string.

Both identifiers are usually generated from a pseudo-random source during system installation and stay constant for all subsequent boots. Optionally, for stateless systems, they are generated during runtime at early boot if found to be empty. They don't change based on user configuration or when hardware is replaced.
The two machine identifiers differ in protection and usage:

listitem.para: The machine ID that adheres to the same format and logic as the D-Bus machine ID.

Programs may use this ID to identify the host with a globally unique ID in the network, which does not change even if the local network configuration changes. Due to this and its greater length, it is a more useful replacement for the gethostid3 call that POSIX specifies.
The machine secret, owned by the root user and not readable or writeable by any other user.

It is private to the local machine and should be never exposed on the network or to unprivileged users. It can, however, be used as an input to a secure cryptographic hashing function (such as SHA-256) result of which can be exposed without restrictions. Note that MD5 algorithm not considered secure for use with a machine secret.
Machine secret can be used as a secret key when utilizing the method as defined by RFC 7217 to configure the IPv6 addresses.

It must be initialized from a pseudo-random number generator compliant with RFC 4086 security requirements for randomness sources. Both systemd-machine-id-setup1 and systemd-firstboot1 are guaranteed to use such randomness source.

refsect1.para: The systemd-machine-id-setup1 tool may be used by installer tools to initialize the identifiers at install time. Use systemd-firstboot1 to initialize them on mounted (but not booted) system images.

refsect1.title: Relation to OSF UUIDs
refsect1.para: Note that the machine ID historically is not an OSF UUID as defined by RFC 4122, nor a Microsoft GUID; however, starting with systemd v30, newly generated machine IDs do qualify as v4 UUIDs.

refsect1.title: History
refsect1.para: The simple configuration file format of /etc/machine-id originates in the /var/lib/dbus/machine-id file introduced by D-Bus. In fact, this latter file might be a symlink to /etc/machine-id.

The /etc/machine-secret was modelled after /etc/machine-id for applications that need to utilize identifiers that remain stable given the same machine and parameters, but are not predictable by other machines in the network.
